abstract.p: Letter from Susan J Cohen, immigration lawyer, says Immigration and Naturalization's draconian treatment of arriving Chinese businesswoman, described in Aug 31 article, is emblematic of broader national problem that will continue until change is made to 1990 law giving INS inspectors unfettered discretion to turn away arriving visitors and stripping courts of jurisdiction to review INS actions

block.p: Re ''Besmirched 'Deportland' Wrestles With the I.N.S.'' (news article, Aug. 31): The frustration in Portland, Ore., with the Immigration and Naturalization Service's draconian treatment of an arriving Chinese businesswoman is emblematic of a broader national problem.

Re ''Besmirched 'Deportland' Wrestles With the I.N.S.'' (news article, Aug. 31): The frustration in Portland, Ore., with the Immigration and Naturalization Service's draconian treatment of an arriving Chinese businesswoman is emblematic of a broader national problem.

In 1990 Congress passed a new immigration law granting I.N.S. inspectors unfettered discretion to turn away arriving visitors and stripping courts of jurisdiction to review these I.N.S. actions. Until the law is changed again, communities throughout the United States will experience Portland's frustration.
The writer is an immigration lawyer.
